articles.headline: Seeking Next Big Hit, TV Tries Hollywood Hoopla
articles.snippet: The combination of time and money that goes into television shows is starting to resemble the effort that goes into movies.
articles.abstract: The combination of time and money that goes into television shows is starting to resemble the effort that goes into movies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Splashy premieres, extravagant budgets, yearlong advertising campaigns and mind-blowing special effects: the summer movie season may be over but Hollywood’s all-or-nothing mentality has shifted to the small screen.

articles.headline: Senate Reaches Deal to Avert Government Shutdown
articles.snippet: A breakthrough came after FEMA indicated it had enough money to squeak through the end of the fiscal year Friday night, eliminating a chief point of partisan contention.
articles.abstract: A breakthrough came after FEMA indicated it had enough money to squeak through the end of the fiscal year Friday night, eliminating a chief point of partisan contention.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate reached a bipartisan spending agreement on Monday to avert a government shutdown, sidestepping a bitter impasse over disaster financing after federal authorities said they could most likely squeak through the rest of this week with the $114 million they had on hand.

articles.headline: Kodak Stock Dives After Credit Line Is Tapped
articles.snippet: Kodak officials and some analysts played down the significance of the decision, pointing out the seasonal nature of the company’s cash flows.
articles.abstract: Kodak officials and some analysts played down the significance of the decision, pointing out the seasonal nature of the company’s cash flows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eastman Kodak has been struggling to reinvent itself for decades. So when Antonio M. Perez, the chief executive, announced in July that he was confident that Kodak could transform itself into a profitable and sustainable digital company by 2012, many investors were skeptical.

articles.headline: Alcohol Isn’t Worth the Trouble for Some Chain Restaurants
articles.snippet: In an attempt to bolster revenue during rocky economic times, places like Starbucks, Sonic and Burger King are seeing how adding drinks works.
articles.abstract: In an attempt to bolster revenue during rocky economic times, places like Starbucks, Sonic and Burger King are seeing how adding drinks works.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some restaurant chains are turning to the bottle during the rough economy, but the liquoring up has produced mostly headaches, not happiness.

articles.headline: Pakistanis Tied to 2007 Border Attack on Americans
articles.snippet: Details of the ambush suggest officials knew of Pakistan’s sometimes duplicitous role long before it was linked to an attack on the U.S. Embassy in Kabul.
articles.abstract: Details of the ambush suggest officials knew of Pakistan’s sometimes duplicitous role long before it was linked to an attack on the U.S. Embassy in Kabul.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A group of American military officers and Afghan officials had just finished a five-hour meeting with their Pakistani hosts in a village schoolhouse settling a border dispute when they were ambushed — by the Pakistanis.

articles.headline: In North Dakota, Flames of Wasted Natural Gas Light the Prairie
articles.snippet: About 30 percent of the natural gas produced in North Dakota is burned as waste, an amount that no other domestic oil field comes close to.
articles.abstract: About 30 percent of the natural gas produced in North Dakota is burned as waste, an amount that no other domestic oil field comes close to.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW TOWN, N.D. — Across western North Dakota, hundreds of fires rise above fields of wheat and sunflowers and bales of hay. At night, they illuminate the prairie skies like giant fireflies.

articles.headline: Freddie Mac Loan Deal Defective, Report Says
articles.snippet: As a result of faulty methodology, the probable losses by Freddie Mac on mortgage loans it bought from Bank of America have increased significantly.
articles.abstract: As a result of faulty methodology, the probable losses by Freddie Mac on mortgage loans it bought from Bank of America have increased significantly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Freddie Mac used a flawed analysis when it accepted $1.35 billion from Bank of America to settle claims that the bank misled it about loans purchased during the mortgage boom, according to an oversight report scheduled for release on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Nagging Fears on Europe Slow a Wall Street Rally
articles.snippet: A global stock rally lost some steam as solutions to the European sovereign debt crisis remained elusive.
articles.abstract: A global stock rally lost some steam as solutions to the European sovereign debt crisis remained elusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is the rally in the markets showing signs of ending?
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Greek Vote Approves a Despised Property Tax
articles.snippet: The German Parliament will vote on Thursday on a bill to bolster the main European bailout fund.
articles.abstract: The German Parliament will vote on Thursday on a bill to bolster the main European bailout fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Greek Parliament voted late Tuesday in Athens to back a hugely unpopular property tax, one of a series of new austerity measures. The vote could clear the way for a crucial injection of international financing meant to at least temporarily stave off a default on government debt.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: Health Insurance Costs Rising Sharply This Year, Study Shows
articles.snippet: The 9 percent increase this year raised the question of whether sharp rises would continue, the Kaiser Family Foundation said.
articles.abstract: The 9 percent increase this year raised the question of whether sharp rises would continue, the Kaiser Family Foundation said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cost of health insurance for many Americans this year climbed more sharply than in previous years, outstripping any growth in workers’ wages and adding more uncertainty about the pace of rising medical costs.

articles.headline: Fearing Change, Many Christians in Syria Back Assad
articles.snippet: With chaos growing, many Syrian Christians said they feared a change of power could deprive them of the semblance of protection the Assad family has provided.
articles.abstract: With chaos growing, many Syrian Christians said they feared a change of power could deprive them of the semblance of protection the Assad family has provided.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAYDNAYA, Syria — Abu Elias sat beneath the towering stairs leading from the Convent of Our Lady of Saydnaya, a church high up in the mountains outside Damascus, where Christians have worshiped for 1,400 years. “We are all scared of what will come next,” he said, turning to a man seated beside him, Robert, an Iraqi refugee who escaped the sectarian strife in his homeland.
